title: 111_hr5514
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Activity Based Total Accountability Act of 2010." The Congress finds that the Federal Government sends billions of dollars to the States annually for various purposes such as health care, transportation, housing, education, and agriculture. States receive this funding through various means like grants, loans, and direct appropriations. Some States are more effective than others in utilizing these taxpayer dollars. Every State spends money on common activities like health care, transportation, housing, education, and agriculture. Some States are more effective than others in utilizing Federal taxpayer dollars. Taxpayers, legislators, and agencies should be able to objectively compare performance measurements to identify government activities and costs. Activity-based total accountability will show which States are most effective with taxpayer dollars, leading to competition. States demonstrating efficiency with lower activity costs will serve as models for accountability in spending tax dollars. The purpose of this Act is to improve government accountability at the State level by requiring annual accountings in a format that includes unit-cost data. States demonstrating efficiency with lower activity costs will serve as models for accountability in spending tax dollars. State governments receiving Federal financial assistance must submit a State fiscal accounting report to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget 15 days before the end of the Federal fiscal year. The report includes a one-page summary of total funding and expenditures for each budget entity, along with a unit-cost summary for each entity. The Director is required to publish these reports on their website within 30 days of receiving them. SEC. 4. STANDARDIZATION OF STATE FISCAL ACCOUNTING REPORTS. The Director will standardize State fiscal accounting reports for comparison. States must submit program descriptions to the Director within 180 days. A classification system will be based on submitted descriptions and relevant data. The Director will establish a uniform system for classifying agency activities based on program descriptions and relevant data, including performance measures. The Director will establish a uniform system for classifying agency activities based on program descriptions and relevant data, including performance measures. Performance measures for each agency activity will be identified and linked electronically to that activity in reports. SEC. 5. UNIT-COST SUMMARY. Each unit-cost summary for a budget entity of a State government shall be one page long and include funds available, agency activities, and a reconciliation of funds with expenditures. SEC. 6. STATEMENT OF FUNDS AVAILABLE. A statement of funds available must identify all sources of funds for expenditure by the budget entity, including State appropriations, Federal financial assistance, and other sources as determined by the Director. SEC. 7. AGENCY ACTIVITY LINE ITEM LISTINGS. The agency activity line item listing must identify the activity, total funds expended, number of activity units, and unit cost. It should also describe conduct, purposes, and intended beneficiaries of the activity. The agency activity line item listing must identify conduct, purposes, and intended beneficiaries of the activity. Expenditures for agency activities must be allocated to similar activities if no measurement method exists. Total funds expended and payments to contractors or subordinate entities must be included. The unit-cost of an agency activity is determined using a specific formula, as per the Director's determination. Total funds expended must include payments to contractors or subordinate entities. The formula for determining the unit-cost of an agency activity includes UC, m, and q as defined terms. Additionally, there is a provision for reconciling funds available with adjusted expenditures. SEC. 8. RECONCILIATION OF FUNDS AVAILABLE WITH ADJUSTED EXPENDITURES. This section outlines the process for reconciling adjusted expenditures of a budget entity with funds available for expenditure or obligation. Adjusted expenditures are determined by the formula AE = EXP + PT + REV. SEC. 9. NONCOMPLIANCE. A budget entity can identify pass-throughs and reversions based on criteria set by the Director. If a State government fails to file a timely fiscal accounting report, the Director will notify Federal departments to withhold 10% of financial assistance for the next year. The Director can create necessary rules, and definitions are provided in the Act. The Director is authorized to make rules for carrying out the Act. Definitions include "State government," "budget entity," "agency activity," and "Federal financial assistance."
